channel.title: 'Mixture' Math Problem
channel.description:
The radiator in a car is filled with a solution of 60% antifreeze and 40% water. The manufacturer of the antifreeze suggests that, for summer driving, optimal cooling of the engine is obtained with only 50% antifreeze. If the capacity of the radiator is 3.6L, how much coolant should be drained and replaced with water to reduce the antifreeze concentration to the recommended level? Answer:0.6L (my friends and i keep getting .36L for this one and are all very angry, im just going to hope the book is wrong for this one :p)
A bottle contains 750mL of fruit punch with a concentration of 50% pure fruit juice. Jill drinks 100mL of the punch and then refills the bottle with an equal amount of a cheaper brand of punch. If the concentration of juice in the bottle is now reduced to 48%, what was the concentration in the bunch that Jill added? Answer:35%
Show work. Very Angry. I Feel Stupid.

item.title: 'Mixture' Math Problem
item.dc:creator: @Boreas Boreas
item.description:
@Boreas wrote:

It says how much coolant should be drained. Coolant is the mixture, 60% antifreeze 40% water. .36L is how much antifreeze should be drained, but its a part of the coolant mixture. So how much mixture do you drain. .36L is 60% of what?

.36=.6*X
X=.36/.6
X=.6

So drain .6L of coolant, 60% of which is antifreeze, which is .36L

Read full topic

item.title: 'Mixture' Math Problem
item.dc:creator: @sidishere sidishere
item.description:
@sidishere wrote:

yoho i just looked over your post again for some reason

for the first one i got the same as your friends have been getting (.36)
60% of 3.6 = 2.16
50% of 3.6 = 1.8
2.16-1.8 = .36

for the second one
i couldnt figure out lol

Read full topic
